t: 2 Samuel 1
Now*p it came to pass after the death of Saul, when David was returned from the slaughter of the Amalekites, and David had abode two days in Ziklag;

It*p came even to pass on the third day, that, behold, a man came out of the camp from Saul with his clothes rent, and earth upon his head: and so it was, when he came to David, that he fell to the earth, and did obeisance.
And*p David said unto him, From whence comest thou? And he said unto him, Out of the camp of Israel am I escaped.

And*p David said unto him, How went the matter? I pray thee, tell me. And he answered, That the people are fled from the battle, and many of the people also are fallen and dead; and Saul and Jonathan his son are dead also.
And*p David said unto the young man that told him, How knowest thou that Saul and Jonathan his son be dead?
And*p the young man that told him said, As I happened by chance upon mount Gilboa, behold, Saul leaned upon his spear; and, lo, the chariots and horsemen followed hard after him.
And*p when he looked behind him, he saw me, and called unto me. And I answered, Here am I.
And*p he said unto me, Who art thou? And I answered him, I am an Amalekite.
He*p said unto me again, Stand, I pray thee, upon me, and slay me: for anguish is come upon me, because my life is yet whole in me.

So*p I stood upon him, and slew him, because I was sure that he could not live after that he was fallen: and I took the crown that was upon his head, and the bracelet that was on his arm, and have brought them hither unto my lord.
Then*p David took hold on his clothes, and rent them; and likewise all the men that were with him:
And*p they mourned, and wept, and fasted until even, for Saul, and for Jonathan his son, and for the people of the Lord,*s and for the house of Israel; because they were fallen by the sword.
And*p David said unto the young man that told him, Whence art thou? And he answered, I am the son of a stranger, an Amalekite.
And*p David said unto him, How wast thou not afraid to stretch forth thine hand to destroy the Lord's*s anointed?
And*p David called one of the young men, and said, Go near, and fall upon him. And he smote him that he died.
And*p David said unto him, Thy blood be upon thy head; for thy mouth hath testified against thee, saying, I have slain the Lord's*s anointed.
And*p David lamented with this lamentation over Saul and over Jonathan his son:
(Also*p he bade them teach the children of Judah the use of the bow: behold, it is written in the book of Jasher.)
The*p beauty of Israel is slain upon thy high places: how are the mighty fallen!
Tell*p it not in Gath, publish it not in the streets of Ashkelon; lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph.

Ye*p mountains of Gilboa, let there be no dew, neither let there be rain, upon you, nor fields of offerings: for there the shield of the mighty is vilely cast away, the shield of Saul, as though he had not been anointed with oil.
From*p the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan turned not back, and the sword of Saul returned not empty.
Saul*p and Jonathan were lovely and pleasant in their lives, and in their death they were not divided: they were swifter than eagles, they were stronger than lions.
Ye*p daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet, with other delights, who put on ornaments of gold upon your apparel.
How*p are the mighty fallen in the midst of the battle! O Jonathan, thou wast slain in thine high places.
I*p am distressed for thee, my brother Jonathan: very pleasant hast thou been unto me: thy love to me was wonderful, passing the love of women.
How*p are the mighty fallen, and the weapons of war perished!
2 Samuel 2

And*p it came to pass after this, that David enquired of the Lord,*s saying, Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah? And the Lord*s said unto him, Go up. And David said, Whither shall I go up? And he said, Unto Hebron.
So*p David went up thither, and his two wives also, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess, and Abigail Nabal's wife the Carmelite.
And*p his men that were with him did David bring up, every man with his household: and they dwelt in the cities of Hebron.
And*p the men of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah. And they told David, saying, That the men of Jabesh–gilead were they that buried Saul.
And*p David sent messengers unto the men of Jabesh–gilead, and said unto them, Blessed be ye of the Lord,*s that ye have shewed this kindness unto your lord, even unto Saul, and have buried him.
And*p now the Lord*s shew kindness and truth unto you: and I also will requite you this kindness, because ye have done this thing.
Therefore*p now let your hands be strengthened, and be ye valiant: for your master Saul is dead, and also the house of Judah have anointed me king over them.
But*p Abner the son of Ner, captain of Saul's host, took Ish–bosheth the son of Saul, and brought him over to Mahanaim;
And*p made him king over Gilead, and over the Ashurites, and over Jezreel, and over Ephraim, and over Benjamin, and over all Israel.
Ish–bosheth*p Saul's son was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and reigned two years. But the house of Judah followed David.
And*p the time that David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.
And*p Abner the son of Ner, and the servants of Ish–bosheth the son of Saul, went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.

And*p Joab the son of Zeruiah, and the servants of David, went out, and met together by the pool of Gibeon: and they sat down, the one on the one side of the pool, and the other on the other side of the pool.
And*p Abner said to Joab, Let the young men now arise, and play before us. And Joab said, Let them arise.
Then*p there arose and went over by number twelve of Benjamin, which pertained to Ish–bosheth the son of Saul, and twelve of the servants of David.
And*p they caught every one his fellow by the head, and thrust his sword in his fellow's side; so they fell down together: wherefore that place was called Helkath–hazzurim, which is in Gibeon.
And*p there was a very sore battle that day; and Abner was beaten, and the men of Israel, before the servants of David.
And*p there were three sons of Zeruiah there, Joab, and Abishai, and Asahel: and Asahel was as light of foot as a wild roe.
And*p Asahel pursued after Abner; and in going he turned not to the right hand nor to the left from following Abner.
Then*p Abner looked behind him, and said, Art thou Asahel? And he answered, I am.
And*p Abner said to him, Turn thee aside to thy right hand or to thy left, and lay thee hold on one of the young men, and take thee his armour. But Asahel would not turn aside from following of him.
And*p Abner said again to Asahel, Turn thee aside from following me: wherefore should I smite thee to the ground? how then should I hold up my face to Joab thy brother?

Howbeit*p he refused to turn aside: wherefore Abner with the hinder end of the spear smote him under the fifth rib, that the spear came out behind him; and he fell down there, and died in the same place: and it came to pass, that as many as came to the place where Asahel fell down and died stood still.
Joab*p also and Abishai pursued after Abner: and the sun went down when they were come to the hill of Ammah, that lieth before Giah by the way of the wilderness of Gibeon.
And*p the children of Benjamin gathered themselves together after Abner, and became one troop, and stood on the top of an hill.

Then*p Abner called to Joab, and said, Shall the sword devour for ever? knowest thou not that it will be bitterness in the latter end? how long shall it be then, ere thou bid the people return from following their brethren?
And*p Joab said, As God liveth, unless thou hadst spoken, surely then in the morning the people had gone up every one from following his brother.
So*p Joab blew a trumpet, and all the people stood still, and pursued after Israel no more, neither fought they any more.
And*p Abner and his men walked all that night through the plain, and passed over Jordan, and went through all Bithron, and they came to Mahanaim.
And*p Joab returned from following Abner: and when he had gathered all the people together, there lacked of David's servants nineteen men and Asahel.
But*p the servants of David had smitten of Benjamin, and of Abner's men, so that three hundred and threescore men died.
And*p they took up Asahel, and buried him in the sepulchre of his father, which was in Beth–lehem. And Joab and his men went all night, and they came to Hebron at break of day.
2 Samuel 3
Now*p there was long war between the house of Saul and the house of David: but David waxed stronger and stronger, and the house of Saul waxed weaker and weaker.
And*p unto David were sons born in Hebron: and his firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam the Jezreelitess;
And*p his second, Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; and the third, Absalom the son of Maacah the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur;
And*p the fourth, Adonijah the son of Haggith; and the fifth, Shephatiah the son of Abital;
And*p the sixth, Ithream, by Eglah David's wife. These were born to David in Hebron.
And*p it came to pass, while there was war between the house of Saul and the house of David, that Abner made himself strong for the house of Saul.
And*p Saul had a concubine, whose name was Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah: and Ish–bosheth said to Abner, Wherefore hast thou gone in unto my father's concubine?

Then*p was Abner very wroth for the words of Ish–bosheth, and said, Am I a dog's head, which against Judah do shew kindness this day unto the house of Saul thy father, to his brethren, and to his friends, and have not delivered thee into the hand of David, that thou chargest me to day with a fault concerning this woman?
So*p do God to Abner, and more also, except, as the Lord*s hath sworn to David, even so I do to him;
To*p translate the kingdom from the house of Saul, and to set up the throne of David over Israel and over Judah, from Dan even to Beer–sheba.
And*p he could not answer Abner a word again, because he feared him.
And*p Abner sent messengers to David on his behalf, saying, Whose is the land? saying also, Make thy league with me, and, behold, my hand shall be with thee, to bring about all Israel unto thee.

And*p he said, Well; I will make a league with thee: but one thing I require of thee, that is, Thou shalt not see my face, except thou first bring Michal Saul's daughter, when thou comest to see my face.
And*p David sent messengers to Ish–bosheth Saul's son, saying, Deliver me my wife Michal, which I espoused to me for an hundred foreskins of the Philistines.
And*p Ish–bosheth sent, and took her from her husband, even from Phaltiel the son of Laish.
And*p her husband went with her along weeping behind her to Bahurim. Then said Abner unto him, Go, return. And he returned.
And*p Abner had communication with the elders of Israel, saying, Ye sought for David in times past to be king over you:

Now*p then do it: for the Lord*s hath spoken of David, saying, By the hand of my servant David I will save my people Israel out of the hand of the Philistines, and out of the hand of all their enemies.
And*p Abner also spake in the ears of Benjamin: and Abner went also to speak in the ears of David in Hebron all that seemed good to Israel, and that seemed good to the whole house of Benjamin.
So*p Abner came to David to Hebron, and twenty men with him. And David made Abner and the men that were with him a feast.

And*p Abner said unto David, I will arise and go, and will gather all Israel unto my lord the king, that they may make a league with thee, and that thou mayest reign over all that thine heart desireth. And David sent Abner away; and he went in peace.

And,*p behold, the servants of David and Joab came from pursuing a troop, and brought in a great spoil with them: but Abner was not with David in Hebron; for he had sent him away, and he was gone in peace.
When*p Joab and all the host that was with him were come, they told Joab, saying, Abner the son of Ner came to the king, and he hath sent him away, and he is gone in peace.
Then*p Joab came to the king, and said, What hast thou done? behold, Abner came unto thee; why is it that thou hast sent him away, and he is quite gone?
Thou*p knowest Abner the son of Ner, that he came to deceive thee, and to know thy going out and thy coming in, and to know all that thou doest.
And*p when Joab was come out from David, he sent messengers after Abner, which brought him again from the well of Sirah: but David knew it not.
And*p when Abner was returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside in the gate to speak with him quietly, and smote him there under the fifth rib, that he died, for the blood of Asahel his brother.
And*p afterward when David heard it, he said, I and my kingdom are guiltless before the Lord*s for ever from the blood of Abner the son of Ner:

Let*p it rest on the head of Joab, and on all his father's house; and let there not fail from the house of Joab one that hath an issue, or that is a leper, or that leaneth on a staff, or that falleth on the sword, or that lacketh bread.
So*p Joab and Abishai his brother slew Abner, because he had slain their brother Asahel at Gibeon in the battle.
And*p David said to Joab, and to all the people that were with him, Rend your clothes, and gird you with sackcloth, and mourn before Abner. And king David himself followed the bier.
And*p they buried Abner in Hebron: and the king lifted up his voice, and wept at the grave of Abner; and all the people wept.
And*p the king lamented over Abner, and said, Died Abner as a fool dieth?
Thy*p hands were not bound, nor thy feet put into fetters: as a man falleth before wicked men, so fellest thou. And all the people wept again over him.
And*p when all the people came to cause David to eat meat while it was yet day, David sware, saying, So do God to me, and more also, if I taste bread, or ought else, till the sun be down.
And*p all the people took notice of it, and it pleased them: as whatsoever the king did pleased all the people.
For*p all the people and all Israel understood that day that it was not of the king to slay Abner the son of Ner.
And*p the king said unto his servants, Know ye not that there is a prince and a great man fallen this day in Israel?
And*p I am this day weak, though anointed king; and these men the sons of Zeruiah be too hard for me: the Lord*s shall reward the doer of evil according to his wickedness.
2 Samuel 4
And*p when Saul's son heard that Abner was dead in Hebron, his hands were feeble, and all the Israelites were troubled.

And*p Saul's son had two men that were captains of bands: the name of the one was Baanah, and the name of the other Rechab, the sons of Rimmon a Beerothite, of the children of Benjamin: (for Beeroth also was reckoned to Benjamin:
And*p the Beerothites fled to Gittaim, and were sojourners there until this day.)

And*p Jonathan, Saul's son, had a son that was lame of his feet. He was five years old when the tidings came of Saul and Jonathan out of Jezreel, and his nurse took him up, and fled: and it came to pass, as she made haste to flee, that he fell, and became lame. And his name was Mephibosheth.
And*p the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, went, and came about the heat of the day to the house of Ish–bosheth, who lay on a bed at noon.
And*p they came thither into the midst of the house, as though they would have fetched wheat; and they smote him under the fifth rib: and Rechab and Baanah his brother escaped.
For*p when they came into the house, he lay on his bed in his bedchamber, and they smote him, and slew him, and beheaded him, and took his head, and gat them away through the plain all night.

And*p they brought the head of Ish–bosheth unto David to Hebron, and said to the king, Behold the head of Ish–bosheth the son of Saul thine enemy, which sought thy life; and the Lord*s hath avenged my lord the king this day of Saul, and of his seed.
And*p David answered Rechab and Baanah his brother, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, and said unto them, As the Lord*s liveth, who hath redeemed my soul out of all adversity,
When*p one told me, saying, Behold, Saul is dead, thinking to have brought good tidings, I took hold of him, and slew him in Ziklag, who thought that I would have given him a reward for his tidings:
How*p much more, when wicked men have slain a righteous person in his own house upon his bed? shall I not therefore now require his blood of your hand, and take you away from the earth?

And*p David commanded his young men, and they slew them, and cut off their hands and their feet, and hanged them up over the pool in Hebron. But they took the head of Ish–bosheth, and buried it in the sepulchre of Abner in Hebron.
2 Samuel 5
Then*p came all the tribes of Israel to David unto Hebron, and spake, saying, Behold, we are thy bone and thy flesh.

Also*p in time past, when Saul was king over us, thou wast he that leddest out and broughtest in Israel: and the Lord*s said to thee, Thou shalt feed my people Israel, and thou shalt be a captain over Israel.
So*p all the elders of Israel came to the king to Hebron; and king David made a league with them in Hebron before the Lord:*s and they anointed David king over Israel.
David*p was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years.
In*p Hebron he reigned over Judah seven years and six months: and in Jerusalem he reigned thirty and three years over all Israel and Judah.

And*p the king and his men went to Jerusalem unto the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land: which spake unto David, saying, Except thou take away the blind and the lame, thou shalt not come in hither: thinking, David cannot come in hither.
Nevertheless*p David took the strong hold of Zion: the same is the city of David.

And*p David said on that day, Whosoever getteth up to the gutter, and smiteth the Jebusites, and the lame and the blind, that are hated of David's soul, he shall be chief and captain. Wherefore they said, The blind and the lame shall not come into the house.
So*p David dwelt in the fort, and called it the city of David. And David built round about from Millo and inward.
And*p David went on, and grew great, and the Lord*s God of hosts was with him.
And*p Hiram king of Tyre sent messengers to David, and cedar trees, and carpenters, and masons: and they built David an house.
And*p David perceived that the Lord*s had established him king over Israel, and that he had exalted his kingdom for his people Israel's sake.
And*p David took him more concubines and wives out of Jerusalem, after he was come from Hebron: and there were yet sons and daughters born to David.
And*p these be the names of those that were born unto him in Jerusalem; Shammua, and Shobab, and Nathan, and Solomon,
Ibhar*p also, and Elishua, and Nepheg, and Japhia,
And*p Elishama, and Eliada, and Eliphelet.
But*p when the Philistines heard that they had anointed David king over Israel, all the Philistines came up to seek David; and David heard of it, and went down to the hold.
The*p Philistines also came and spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

And*p David enquired of the Lord,*s saying, Shall I go up to the Philistines? wilt thou deliver them into mine hand? And the Lord*s said unto David, Go up: for I will doubtless deliver the Philistines into thine hand.

And*p David came to Baal–perazim, and David smote them there, and said, The Lord*s hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of waters. Therefore he called the name of that place Baal–perazim.
And*p there they left their images, and David and his men burned them.
And*p the Philistines came up yet again, and spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.
And*p when David enquired of the Lord,*s he said, Thou shalt not go up; but fetch a compass behind them, and come upon them over against the mulberry trees.

And*p let it be, when thou hearest the sound of a going in the tops of the mulberry trees, that then thou shalt bestir thyself: for then shall the Lord*s go out before thee, to smite the host of the Philistines.
And*p David did so, as the Lord*s had commanded him; and smote the Philistines from Geba until thou come to Gezer.
2 Samuel 6
Again,*p David gathered together all the chosen men of Israel, thirty thousand.

And*p David arose, and went with all the people that were with him from Baale of Judah, to bring up from thence the ark of God, whose name is called by the name of the Lord*s of hosts that dwelleth between the cherubims.
And*p they set the ark of God upon a new cart, and brought it out of the house of Abinadab that was in Gibeah: and Uzza and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, drave the new cart.
And*p they brought it out of the house of Abinadab which was at Gibeah, accompanying the ark of God: and Ahio went before the ark.
And*p David and all the house of Israel played before the Lord*s on all manner of instruments made of fir wood, even on harps, and on psalteries, and on timbrels, and on cornets, and on cymbals.
And*p when they came to Nachon's threshingfloor, Uzza put forth his hand to the ark of God, and took hold of it; for the oxen shook it.
And*p the anger of the Lord*s was kindled against Uzza; and God smote him there for his error; and there he died by the ark of God.
And*p David was displeased, because the Lord*s had made a breach upon Uzza: and he called the name of the place Perez–uzzah to this day.
And*p David was afraid of the Lord*s that day, and said, How shall the ark of the Lord*s come to me?
So*p David would not remove the ark of the Lord*s unto him into the city of David: but David carried it aside into the house of Obed–edom the Gittite.
And*p the ark of the Lord*s continued in the house of Obed–edom the Gittite three months: and the Lord*s blessed Obed–edom, and all his household.

And*p it was told king David, saying, The Lord*s hath blessed the house of Obed–edom, and all that pertaineth unto him, because of the ark of God. So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed–edom into the city of David with gladness.
And*p it was so, that when they that bare the ark of the Lord*s had gone six paces, he sacrificed oxen and fatlings.
And*p David danced before the Lord*s with all his might; and David was girded with a linen ephod.
So*p David and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the Lord*s with shouting, and with the sound of the trumpet.

And*p as the ark of the Lord*s came into the city of David, Michal Saul's daughter looked through a window, and saw king David leaping and dancing before the Lord;*s and she despised him in her heart.

And*p they brought in the ark of the Lord,*s and set it in his place, in the midst of the tabernacle that David had pitched for it: and David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.*s
And*p as soon as David had made an end of offering burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the Lord*s of hosts.

And*p he dealt among all the people, even among the whole multitude of Israel, as well to the women as men, to every one a cake of bread, and a good piece of flesh, and a flagon of wine. So all the people departed every one to his house.

Then*p David returned to bless his household. And Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet David, and said, How glorious was the king of Israel to day, who uncovered himself to day in the eyes of the handmaids of his servants, as one of the vain fellows shamelessly uncovereth himself!

And*p David said unto Michal, It was before the Lord,*s which chose me before thy father, and before all his house, to appoint me ruler over the people of the Lord,*s over Israel: therefore will I play before the Lord.*s
And*p I will yet be more vile than thus, and will be base in mine own sight: and of the maidservants which thou hast spoken of, of them shall I be had in honour.
Therefore*p Michal the daughter of Saul had no child unto the day of her death.
2 Samuel 7
And*p it came to pass, when the king sat in his house, and the Lord*s had given him rest round about from all his enemies;
That*p the king said unto Nathan the prophet, See now, I dwell in an house of cedar, but the ark of God dwelleth within curtains.
And*p Nathan said to the king, Go, do all that is in thine heart; for the Lord*s is with thee.
And*p it came to pass that night, that the word of the Lord*s came unto Nathan, saying,
Go*p and tell my servant David, Thus saith the Lord,*s Shalt thou build me an house for me to dwell in?
Whereas*p I have not dwelt in any house since the time that I brought up the children of Israel out of Egypt, even to this day, but have walked in a tent and in a tabernacle.

In*p all the places wherein I have walked with all the children of Israel spake I a word with any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to feed my people Israel, saying, Why build ye not me an house of cedar?
Now*p therefore so shalt thou say unto my servant David, Thus saith the Lord*s of hosts, I took thee from the sheepcote, from following the sheep, to be ruler over my people, over Israel:
And*p I was with thee whithersoever thou wentest, and have cut off all thine enemies out of thy sight, and have made thee a great name, like unto the name of the great men that are in the earth.

Moreover*p I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and will plant them, that they may dwell in a place of their own, and move no more; neither shall the children of wickedness afflict them any more, as beforetime,
And*p as since the time that I commanded judges to be over my people Israel, and have caused thee to rest from all thine enemies. Also the Lord*s telleth thee that he will make thee an house.
And*p when thy days be fulfilled, and thou shalt sleep with thy fathers, I will set up thy seed after thee, which shall proceed out of thy bowels, and I will establish his kingdom.
He*p shall build an house for my name, and I will stablish the throne of his kingdom for ever.
I*p will be his father, and he shall be my son. If he commit iniquity, I will chasten him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men:
But*p my mercy shall not depart away from him, as I took it from Saul, whom I put away before thee.
And*p thine house and thy kingdom shall be established for ever before thee: thy throne shall be established for ever.
According*p to all these words, and according to all this vision, so did Nathan speak unto David.
Then*p went king David in, and sat before the Lord,*s and he said, Who am I, O Lord God?*s and what is my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto?
And*p this was yet a small thing in thy sight, O Lord God;*s but thou hast spoken also of thy servant's house for a great while to come. And is this the manner of man, O Lord God?*s
And*p what can David say more unto thee? for thou, Lord God,*s knowest thy servant.
For*p thy word's sake, and according to thine own heart, hast thou done all these great things, to make thy servant know them.
Wherefore*p thou art great, O Lord*s God: for there is none like thee, neither is there any God beside thee, according to all that we have heard with our ears.

And*p what one nation in the earth is like thy people, even like Israel, whom God went to redeem for a people to himself, and to make him a name, and to do for you great things and terrible, for thy land, before thy people, which thou redeemedst to thee from Egypt, from the nations and their gods?
For*p thou hast confirmed to thyself thy people Israel to be a people unto thee for ever: and thou, Lord,*s art become their God.
And*p now, O Lord*s God, the word that thou hast spoken concerning thy servant, and concerning his house, establish it for ever, and do as thou hast said.
And*p let thy name be magnified for ever, saying, The Lord*s of hosts is the God over Israel: and let the house of thy servant David be established before thee.
For*p thou, O Lord*s of hosts, God of Israel, hast revealed to thy servant, saying, I will build thee an house: therefore hath thy servant found in his heart to pray this prayer unto thee.
And*p now, O Lord God,*s thou art that God, and thy words be true, and thou hast promised this goodness unto thy servant:

Therefore*p now let it please thee to bless the house of thy servant, that it may continue for ever before thee: for thou, O Lord God,*s hast spoken it: and with thy blessing let the house of thy servant be blessed for ever.
2 Samuel 8
And*p after this it came to pass, that David smote the Philistines, and subdued them: and David took Metheg–ammah out of the hand of the Philistines.

And*p he smote Moab, and measured them with a line, casting them down to the ground; even with two lines measured he to put to death, and with one full line to keep alive. And so the Moabites became David's servants, and brought gifts.
David*p smote also Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to recover his border at the river Euphrates.
And*p David took from him a thousand chariots, and seven hundred horsemen, and twenty thousand footmen: and David houghed all the chariot horses, but reserved of them for an hundred chariots.
And*p when the Syrians of Damascus came to succour Hadadezer king of Zobah, David slew of the Syrians two and twenty thousand men.
Then*p David put garrisons in Syria of Damascus: and the Syrians became servants to David, and brought gifts. And the Lord*s preserved David whithersoever he went.
And*p David took the shields of gold that were on the servants of Hadadezer, and brought them to Jerusalem.
And*p from Betah, and from Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, king David took exceeding much brass.
When*p Toi king of Hamath heard that David had smitten all the host of Hadadezer,

Then*p Toi sent Joram his son unto king David, to salute him, and to bless him, because he had fought against Hadadezer, and smitten him: for Hadadezer had wars with Toi. And Joram brought with him vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and vessels of brass:
Which*p also king David did dedicate unto the Lord,*s with the silver and gold that he had dedicated of all nations which he subdued;
Of*p Syria, and of Moab, and of the children of Ammon, and of the Philistines, and of Amalek, and of the spoil of Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
And*p David gat him a name when he returned from smiting of the Syrians in the valley of salt, being eighteen thousand men.
And*p he put garrisons in Edom; throughout all Edom put he garrisons, and all they of Edom became David's servants. And the Lord*s preserved David whithersoever he went.
And*p David reigned over all Israel; and David executed judgment and justice unto all his people.
And*p Joab the son of Zeruiah was over the host; and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder;
And*p Zadok the son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, were the priests; and Seraiah was the scribe;
And*p Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over both the Cherethites and the Pelethites; and David's sons were chief rulers.
2 Samuel 9
And*p David said, Is there yet any that is left of the house of Saul, that I may shew him kindness for Jonathan's sake?
And*p there was of the house of Saul a servant whose name was Ziba. And when they had called him unto David, the king said unto him, Art thou Ziba? And he said, Thy servant is he.
And*p the king said, Is there not yet any of the house of Saul, that I may shew the kindness of God unto him? And Ziba said unto the king, Jonathan hath yet a son, which is lame on his feet.
And*p the king said unto him, Where is he? And Ziba said unto the king, Behold, he is in the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, in Lo–debar.
Then*p king David sent, and fetched him out of the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, from Lo–debar.
Now*p when Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, was come unto David, he fell on his face, and did reverence. And David said, Mephibosheth. And he answered, Behold thy servant!

And*p David said unto him, Fear not: for I will surely shew thee kindness for Jonathan thy father's sake, and will restore thee all the land of Saul thy father; and thou shalt eat bread at my table continually.
And*p he bowed himself, and said, What is thy servant, that thou shouldest look upon such a dead dog as I am?
Then*p the king called to Ziba, Saul's servant, and said unto him, I have given unto thy master's son all that pertained to Saul and to all his house.

Thou*p therefore, and thy sons, and thy servants, shall till the land for him, and thou shalt bring in the fruits, that thy master's son may have food to eat: but Mephibosheth thy master's son shall eat bread alway at my table. Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.

Then*p said Ziba unto the king, According to all that my lord the king hath commanded his servant, so shall thy servant do. As for Mephibosheth, said the king, he shall eat at my table, as one of the king's sons.
And*p Mephibosheth had a young son, whose name was Micha. And all that dwelt in the house of Ziba were servants unto Mephibosheth.
So*p Mephibosheth dwelt in Jerusalem: for he did eat continually at the king's table; and was lame on both his feet.
2 Samuel 10
And*p it came to pass after this, that the king of the children of Ammon died, and Hanun his son reigned in his stead.

Then*p said David, I will shew kindness unto Hanun the son of Nahash, as his father shewed kindness unto me. And David sent to comfort him by the hand of his servants for his father. And David's servants came into the land of the children of Ammon.

And*p the princes of the children of Ammon said unto Hanun their lord, Thinkest thou that David doth honour thy father, that he hath sent comforters unto thee? hath not David rather sent his servants unto thee, to search the city, and to spy it out, and to overthrow it?
Wherefore*p Hanun took David's servants, and shaved off the one half of their beards, and cut off their garments in the middle, even to their buttocks, and sent them away.
When*p they told it unto David, he sent to meet them, because the men were greatly ashamed: and the king said, Tarry at Jericho until your beards be grown, and then return.

And*p when the children of Ammon saw that they stank before David, the children of Ammon sent and hired the Syrians of Beth–rehob, and the Syrians of Zobah, twenty thousand footmen, and of king Maacah a thousand men, and of Ish–tob twelve thousand men.
And*p when David heard of it, he sent Joab, and all the host of the mighty men.
And*p the children of Ammon came out, and put the battle in array at the entering in of the gate: and the Syrians of Zobah, and of Rehob, and Ish–tob, and Maacah, were by themselves in the field.
When*p Joab saw that the front of the battle was against him before and behind, he chose of all the choice men of Israel, and put them in array against the Syrians:
And*p the rest of the people he delivered into the hand of Abishai his brother, that he might put them in array against the children of Ammon.
And*p he said, If the Syrians be too strong for me, then thou shalt help me: but if the children of Ammon be too strong for thee, then I will come and help thee.
Be*p of good courage, and let us play the men for our people, and for the cities of our God: and the Lord*s do that which seemeth him good.
And*p Joab drew nigh, and the people that were with him, unto the battle against the Syrians: and they fled before him.
And*p when the children of Ammon saw that the Syrians were fled, then fled they also before Abishai, and entered into the city. So Joab returned from the children of Ammon, and came to Jerusalem.
And*p when the Syrians saw that they were smitten before Israel, they gathered themselves together.
And*p Hadadezer sent, and brought out the Syrians that were beyond the river: and they came to Helam; and Shobach the captain of the host of Hadadezer went before them.
And*p when it was told David, he gathered all Israel together, and passed over Jordan, and came to Helam. And the Syrians set themselves in array against David, and fought with him.
And*p the Syrians fled before Israel; and David slew the men of seven hundred chariots of the Syrians, and forty thousand horsemen, and smote Shobach the captain of their host, who died there.

And*p when all the kings that were servants to Hadadezer saw that they were smitten before Israel, they made peace with Israel, and served them. So the Syrians feared to help the children of Ammon any more.
2 Samuel 11

And*p it came to pass, after the year was expired, at the time when kings go forth to battle, that David sent Joab, and his servants with him, and all Israel; and they destroyed the children of Ammon, and besieged Rabbah. But David tarried still at Jerusalem.

And*p it came to pass in an eveningtide, that David arose from off his bed, and walked upon the roof of the king's house: and from the roof he saw a woman washing herself; and the woman was very beautiful to look upon.
And*p David sent and enquired after the woman. And one said, Is not this Bath–sheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?
And*p David sent messengers, and took her; and she came in unto him, and he lay with her; for she was purified from her uncleanness: and she returned unto her house.
And*p the woman conceived, and sent and told David, and said, I am with child.
And*p David sent to Joab, saying, Send me Uriah the Hittite. And Joab sent Uriah to David.
And*p when Uriah was come unto him, David demanded of him how Joab did, and how the people did, and how the war prospered.
And*p David said to Uriah, Go down to thy house, and wash thy feet. And Uriah departed out of the king's house, and there followed him a mess of meat from the king.
But*p Uriah slept at the door of the king's house with all the servants of his lord, and went not down to his house.
And*p when they had told David, saying, Uriah went not down unto his house, David said unto Uriah, Camest thou not from thy journey? why then didst thou not go down unto thine house?

And*p Uriah said unto David, The ark, and Israel, and Judah, abide in tents; and my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, are encamped in the open fields; shall I then go into mine house, to eat and to drink, and to lie with my wife? as thou livest, and as thy soul liveth, I will not do this thing.
And*p David said to Uriah, Tarry here to day also, and to morrow I will let thee depart. So Uriah abode in Jerusalem that day, and the morrow.
And*p when David had called him, he did eat and drink before him; and he made him drunk: and at even he went out to lie on his bed with the servants of his lord, but went not down to his house.
And*p it came to pass in the morning, that David wrote a letter to Joab, and sent it by the hand of Uriah.
And*p he wrote in the letter, saying, Set ye Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle, and retire ye from him, that he may be smitten, and die.
And*p it came to pass, when Joab observed the city, that he assigned Uriah unto a place where he knew that valiant men were.
And*p the men of the city went out, and fought with Joab: and there fell some of the people of the servants of David; and Uriah the Hittite died also.
Then*p Joab sent and told David all the things concerning the war;
And*p charged the messenger, saying, When thou hast made an end of telling the matters of the war unto the king,
And*p if so be that the king's wrath arise, and he say unto thee, Wherefore approached ye so nigh unto the city when ye did fight? knew ye not that they would shoot from the wall?

Who*p smote Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth? did not a woman cast a piece of a millstone upon him from the wall, that he died in Thebez? why went ye nigh the wall? then say thou, Thy servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.
So*p the messenger went, and came and shewed David all that Joab had sent him for.
And*p the messenger said unto David, Surely the men prevailed against us, and came out unto us into the field, and we were upon them even unto the entering of the gate.
And*p the shooters shot from off the wall upon thy servants; and some of the king's servants be dead, and thy servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.

Then*p David said unto the messenger, Thus shalt thou say unto Joab, Let not this thing displease thee, for the sword devoureth one as well as another: make thy battle more strong against the city, and overthrow it: and encourage thou him.
And*p when the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband.
And*p when the mourning was past, David sent and fetched her to his house, and she became his wife, and bare him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the Lord.*s
2 Samuel 12
And*p the Lord*s sent Nathan unto David. And he came unto him, and said unto him, There were two men in one city; the one rich, and the other poor.
The*p rich man had exceeding many flocks and herds:

But*p the poor man had nothing, save one little ewe lamb, which he had bought and nourished up: and it grew up together with him, and with his children; it did eat of his own meat, and drank of his own cup, and lay in his bosom, and was unto him as a daughter.

And*p there came a traveller unto the rich man, and he spared to take of his own flock and of his own herd, to dress for the wayfaring man that was come unto him; but took the poor man's lamb, and dressed it for the man that was come to him.
And*p David's anger was greatly kindled against the man; and he said to Nathan, As the Lord*s liveth, the man that hath done this thing shall surely die:
And*p he shall restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing, and because he had no pity.
And*p Nathan said to David, Thou art the man. Thus saith the Lord*s God of Israel, I anointed thee king over Israel, and I delivered thee out of the hand of Saul;

And*p I gave thee thy master's house, and thy master's wives into thy bosom, and gave thee the house of Israel and of Judah; and if that had been too little, I would moreover have given unto thee such and such things.

Wherefore*p hast thou despised the commandment of the Lord,*s to do evil in his sight? thou hast killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword, and hast taken his wife to be thy wife, and hast slain him with the sword of the children of Ammon.
Now*p therefore the sword shall never depart from thine house; because thou hast despised me, and hast taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be thy wife.

Thus*p saith the Lord,*s Behold, I will raise up evil against thee out of thine own house, and I will take thy wives before thine eyes, and give them unto thy neighbour, and he shall lie with thy wives in the sight of this sun.
For*p thou didst it secretly: but I will do this thing before all Israel, and before the sun.
And*p David said unto Nathan, I have sinned against the Lord.*s And Nathan said unto David, The Lord*s also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die.
Howbeit,*p because by this deed thou hast given great occasion to the enemies of the Lord*s to blaspheme, the child also that is born unto thee shall surely die.
And*p Nathan departed unto his house. And the Lord*s struck the child that Uriah's wife bare unto David, and it was very sick.
David*p therefore besought God for the child; and David fasted, and went in, and lay all night upon the earth.
And*p the elders of his house arose, and went to him, to raise him up from the earth: but he would not, neither did he eat bread with them.

And*p it came to pass on the seventh day, that the child died. And the servants of David feared to tell him that the child was dead: for they said, Behold, while the child was yet alive, we spake unto him, and he would not hearken unto our voice: how will he then vex himself, if we tell him that the child is dead?
But*p when David saw that his servants whispered, David perceived that the child was dead: therefore David said unto his servants, Is the child dead? And they said, He is dead.

Then*p David arose from the earth, and washed, and anointed himself, and changed his apparel, and came into the house of the Lord,*s and worshipped: then he came to his own house; and when he required, they set bread before him, and he did eat.
Then*p said his servants unto him, What thing is this that thou hast done? thou didst fast and weep for the child, while it was alive; but when the child was dead, thou didst rise and eat bread.
And*p he said, While the child was yet alive, I fasted and wept: for I said, Who can tell whether God*s will be gracious to me, that the child may live?
But*p now he is dead, wherefore should I fast? can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he shall not return to me.
And*p David comforted Bath–sheba his wife, and went in unto her, and lay with her: and she bare a son, and he called his name Solomon: and the Lord*s loved him.
And*p he sent by the hand of Nathan the prophet; and he called his name Jedidiah, because of the Lord.*s
And*p Joab fought against Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and took the royal city.
And*p Joab sent messengers to David, and said, I have fought against Rabbah, and have taken the city of waters.
Now*p therefore gather the rest of the people together, and encamp against the city, and take it: lest I take the city, and it be called after my name.
And*p David gathered all the people together, and went to Rabbah, and fought against it, and took it.

And*p he took their king's crown from off his head, the weight whereof was a talent of gold with the precious stones: and it was set on David's head. And he brought forth the spoil of the city in great abundance.

And*p he brought forth the people that were therein, and put them under saws, and under harrows of iron, and under axes of iron, and made them pass through the brickkiln: and thus did he unto all the cities of the children of Ammon. So David and all the people returned unto Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 13
And*p it came to pass after this, that Absalom the son of David had a fair sister, whose name was Tamar; and Amnon the son of David loved her.
And*p Amnon was so vexed, that he fell sick for his sister Tamar; for she was a virgin; and Amnon thought it hard for him to do any thing to her.
But*p Amnon had a friend, whose name was Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David's brother: and Jonadab was a very subtil man.
And*p he said unto him, Why art thou, being the king's son, lean from day to day? wilt thou not tell me? And Amnon said unto him, I love Tamar, my brother Absalom's sister.

And*p Jonadab said unto him, Lay thee down on thy bed, and make thyself sick: and when thy father cometh to see thee, say unto him, I pray thee, let my sister Tamar come, and give me meat, and dress the meat in my sight, that I may see it, and eat it at her hand.

So*p Amnon lay down, and made himself sick: and when the king was come to see him, Amnon said unto the king, I pray thee, let Tamar my sister come, and make me a couple of cakes in my sight, that I may eat at her hand.
Then*p David sent home to Tamar, saying, Go now to thy brother Amnon's house, and dress him meat.
So*p Tamar went to her brother Amnon's house; and he was laid down. And she took flour, and kneaded it, and made cakes in his sight, and did bake the cakes.
And*p she took a pan, and poured them out before him; but he refused to eat. And Amnon said, Have out all men from me. And they went out every man from him.
And*p Amnon said unto Tamar, Bring the meat into the chamber, that I may eat of thine hand. And Tamar took the cakes which she had made, and brought them into the chamber to Amnon her brother.
And*p when she had brought them unto him to eat, he took hold of her, and said unto her, Come lie with me, my sister.
And*p she answered him, Nay, my brother, do not force me; for no such thing ought to be done in Israel: do not thou this folly.
And*p I, whither shall I cause my shame to go? and as for thee, thou shalt be as one of the fools in Israel. Now therefore, I pray thee, speak unto the king; for he will not withhold me from thee.
Howbeit*p he would not hearken unto her voice: but, being stronger than she, forced her, and lay with her.
Then*p Amnon hated her exceedingly; so that the hatred wherewith he hated her was greater than the love wherewith he had loved her. And Amnon said unto her, Arise, be gone.
And*p she said unto him, There is no cause: this evil in sending me away is greater than the other that thou didst unto me. But he would not hearken unto her.
Then*p he called his servant that ministered unto him, and said, Put now this woman out from me, and bolt the door after her.
And*p she had a garment of divers colours upon her: for with such robes were the king's daughters that were virgins apparelled. Then his servant brought her out, and bolted the door after her.
And*p Tamar put ashes on her head, and rent her garment of divers colours that was on her, and laid her hand on her head, and went on crying.

And*p Absalom her brother said unto her, Hath Amnon thy brother been with thee? but hold now thy peace, my sister: he is thy brother; regard not this thing. So Tamar remained desolate in her brother Absalom's house.
But*p when king David heard of all these things, he was very wroth.
And*p Absalom spake unto his brother Amnon neither good nor bad: for Absalom hated Amnon, because he had forced his sister Tamar.
And*p it came to pass after two full years, that Absalom had sheepshearers in Baal–hazor, which is beside Ephraim: and Absalom invited all the king's sons.
And*p Absalom came to the king, and said, Behold now, thy servant hath sheepshearers; let the king, I beseech thee, and his servants go with thy servant.
And*p the king said to Absalom, Nay, my son, let us not all now go, lest we be chargeable unto thee. And he pressed him: howbeit he would not go, but blessed him.
Then*p said Absalom, If not, I pray thee, let my brother Amnon go with us. And the king said unto him, Why should he go with thee?
But*p Absalom pressed him, that he let Amnon and all the king's sons go with him.

Now*p Absalom had commanded his servants, saying, Mark ye now when Amnon's heart is merry with wine, and when I say unto you, Smite Amnon; then kill him, fear not: have not I commanded you? be courageous, and be valiant.
And*p the servants of Absalom did unto Amnon as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king's sons arose, and every man gat him up upon his mule, and fled.
And*p it came to pass, while they were in the way, that tidings came to David, saying, Absalom hath slain all the king's sons, and there is not one of them left.
Then*p the king arose, and tare his garments, and lay on the earth; and all his servants stood by with their clothes rent.

And*p Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David's brother, answered and said, Let not my lord suppose that they have slain all the young men the king's sons; for Amnon only is dead: for by the appointment of Absalom this hath been determined from the day that he forced his sister Tamar.
Now*p therefore let not my lord the king take the thing to his heart, to think that all the king's sons are dead: for Amnon only is dead.
But*p Absalom fled. And the young man that kept the watch lifted up his eyes, and looked, and, behold, there came much people by the way of the hill side behind him.
And*p Jonadab said unto the king, Behold, the king's sons come: as thy servant said, so it is.
And*p it came to pass, as soon as he had made an end of speaking, that, behold, the king's sons came, and lifted up their voice and wept: and the king also and all his servants wept very sore.
But*p Absalom fled, and went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son every day.
So*p Absalom fled, and went to Geshur, and was there three years.
And*p the soul of king David longed to go forth unto Absalom: for he was comforted concerning Amnon, seeing he was dead.
2 Samuel 14
Now*p Joab the son of Zeruiah perceived that the king's heart was toward Absalom.

And*p Joab sent to Tekoa, and fetched thence a wise woman, and said unto her, I pray thee, feign thyself to be a mourner, and put on now mourning apparel, and anoint not thyself with oil, but be as a woman that had a long time mourned for the dead:
And*p come to the king, and speak on this manner unto him. So Joab put the words in her mouth.
And*p when the woman of Tekoah spake to the king, she fell on her face to the ground, and did obeisance, and said, Help, O king.
And*p the king said unto her, What aileth thee? And she answered, I am indeed a widow woman, and mine husband is dead.
And*p thy handmaid had two sons, and they two strove together in the field, and there was none to part them, but the one smote the other, and slew him.

And,*p behold, the whole family is risen against thine handmaid, and they said, Deliver him that smote his brother, that we may kill him, for the life of his brother whom he slew; and we will destroy the heir also: and so they shall quench my coal which is left, and shall not leave to my husband neither name nor remainder upon the earth.
And*p the king said unto the woman, Go to thine house, and I will give charge concerning thee.
And*p the woman of Tekoah said unto the king, My lord, O king, the iniquity be on me, and on my father's house: and the king and his throne be guiltless.
And*p the king said, Whosoever saith ought unto thee, bring him to me, and he shall not touch thee any more.

Then*p said she, I pray thee, let the king remember the Lord*s thy God, that thou wouldest not suffer the revengers of blood to destroy any more, lest they destroy my son. And he said, As the Lord*s liveth, there shall not one hair of thy son fall to the earth.
Then*p the woman said, Let thine handmaid, I pray thee, speak one word unto my lord the king. And he said, Say on.

And*p the woman said, Wherefore then hast thou thought such a thing against the people of God? for the king doth speak this thing as one which is faulty, in that the king doth not fetch home again his banished.

For*p we must needs die, and are as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again; neither doth God respect any person: yet doth he devise means, that his banished be not expelled from him.

Now*p therefore that I am come to speak of this thing unto my lord the king, it is because the people have made me afraid: and thy handmaid said, I will now speak unto the king; it may be that the king will perform the request of his handmaid.
For*p the king will hear, to deliver his handmaid out of the hand of the man that would destroy me and my son together out of the inheritance of God.

Then*p thine handmaid said, The word of my lord the king shall now be comfortable: for as an angel of God, so is my lord the king to discern good and bad: therefore the Lord*s thy God will be with thee.
Then*p the king answered and said unto the woman, Hide not from me, I pray thee, the thing that I shall ask thee. And the woman said, Let my lord the king now speak.

And*p the king said, Is not the hand of Joab with thee in all this? And the woman answered and said, As thy soul liveth, my lord the king, none can turn to the right hand or to the left from ought that my lord the king hath spoken: for thy servant Joab, he bade me, and he put all these words in the mouth of thine handmaid:
To*p fetch about this form of speech hath thy servant Joab done this thing: and my lord is wise, according to the wisdom of an angel of God, to know all things that are in the earth.
And*p the king said unto Joab, Behold now, I have done this thing: go therefore, bring the young man Absalom again.

And*p Joab fell to the ground on his face, and bowed himself, and thanked the king: and Joab said, To day thy servant knoweth that I have found grace in thy sight, my lord, O king, in that the king hath fulfilled the request of his servant.
So*p Joab arose and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
And*p the king said, Let him turn to his own house, and let him not see my face. So Absalom returned to his own house, and saw not the king's face.
But*p in all Israel there was none to be so much praised as Absalom for his beauty: from the sole of his foot even to the crown of his head there was no blemish in him.

And*p when he polled his head, (for it was at every year's end that he polled it: because the hair was heavy on him, therefore he polled it:) he weighed the hair of his head at two hundred shekels after the king's weight.
And*p unto Absalom there were born three sons, and one daughter, whose name was Tamar: she was a woman of a fair countenance.
So*p Absalom dwelt two full years in Jerusalem, and saw not the king's face.
Therefore*p Absalom sent for Joab, to have sent him to the king; but he would not come to him: and when he sent again the second time, he would not come.
Therefore*p he said unto his servants, See, Joab's field is near mine, and he hath barley there; go and set it on fire. And Absalom's servants set the field on fire.
Then*p Joab arose, and came to Absalom unto his house, and said unto him, Wherefore have thy servants set my field on fire?

And*p Absalom answered Joab, Behold, I sent unto thee, saying, Come hither, that I may send thee to the king, to say, Wherefore am I come from Geshur? it had been good for me to have been there still: now therefore let me see the king's face; and if there be any iniquity in me, let him kill me.
So*p Joab came to the king, and told him: and when he had called for Absalom, he came to the king, and bowed himself on his face to the ground before the king: and the king kissed Absalom.
2 Samuel 15
And*p it came to pass after this, that Absalom prepared him chariots and horses, and fifty men to run before him.

And*p Absalom rose up early, and stood beside the way of the gate: and it was so, that when any man that had a controversy came to the king for judgment, then Absalom called unto him, and said, Of what city art thou? And he said, Thy servant is of one of the tribes of Israel.
And*p Absalom said unto him, See, thy matters are good and right; but there is no man deputed of the king to hear thee.
Absalom*p said moreover, Oh that I were made judge in the land, that every man which hath any suit or cause might come unto me, and I would do him justice!
And*p it was so, that when any man came nigh to him to do him obeisance, he put forth his hand, and took him, and kissed him.
And*p on this manner did Absalom to all Israel that came to the king for judgment: so Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel.
And*p it came to pass after forty years, that Absalom said unto the king, I pray thee, let me go and pay my vow, which I have vowed unto the Lord,*s in Hebron.
For*p thy servant vowed a vow while I abode at Geshur in Syria, saying, If the Lord*s shall bring me again indeed to Jerusalem, then I will serve the Lord.*s
And*p the king said unto him, Go in peace. So he arose, and went to Hebron.
But*p Absalom sent spies throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, As soon as ye hear the sound of the trumpet, then ye shall say, Absalom reigneth in Hebron.
And*p with Absalom went two hundred men out of Jerusalem, that were called; and they went in their simplicity, and they knew not any thing.

And*p Absalom sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David's counsellor, from his city, even from Giloh, while he offered sacrifices. And the conspiracy was strong; for the people increased continually with Absalom.
And*p there came a messenger to David, saying, The hearts of the men of Israel are after Absalom.

And*p David said unto all his servants that were with him at Jerusalem, Arise, and let us flee; for we shall not else escape from Absalom: make speed to depart, lest he overtake us suddenly, and bring evil upon us, and smite the city with the edge of the sword.
And*p the king's servants said unto the king, Behold, thy servants are ready to do whatsoever my lord the king shall appoint.
And*p the king went forth, and all his household after him. And the king left ten women, which were concubines, to keep the house.
And*p the king went forth, and all the people after him, and tarried in a place that was far off.
And*p all his servants passed on beside him; and all the Cherethites, and all the Pelethites, and all the Gittites, six hundred men which came after him from Gath, passed on before the king.
Then*p said the king to Ittai the Gittite, Wherefore goest thou also with us? return to thy place, and abide with the king: for thou art a stranger, and also an exile.
Whereas*p thou camest but yesterday, should I this day make thee go up and down with us? seeing I go whither I may, return thou, and take back thy brethren: mercy and truth be with thee.

And*p Ittai answered the king, and said, As the Lord*s liveth, and as my lord the king liveth, surely in what place my lord the king shall be, whether in death or life, even there also will thy servant be.
And*p David said to Ittai, Go and pass over. And Ittai the Gittite passed over, and all his men, and all the little ones that were with him.
And*p all the country wept with a loud voice, and all the people passed over: the king also himself passed over the brook Kidron, and all the people passed over, toward the way of the wilderness.

And*p lo Zadok also, and all the Levites were with him, bearing the ark of the covenant of God: and they set down the ark of God; and Abiathar went up, until all the people had done passing out of the city.
And*p the king said unto Zadok, Carry back the ark of God into the city: if I shall find favour in the eyes of the Lord,*s he will bring me again, and shew me both it, and his habitation:
But*p if he thus say, I have no delight in thee; behold, here am I, let him do to me as seemeth good unto him.
The*p king said also unto Zadok the priest, Art not thou a seer? return into the city in peace, and your two sons with you, Ahimaaz thy son, and Jonathan the son of Abiathar.
See,*p I will tarry in the plain of the wilderness, until there come word from you to certify me.
Zadok*p therefore and Abiathar carried the ark of God again to Jerusalem: and they tarried there.

And*p David went up by the ascent of mount Olivet, and wept as he went up, and had his head covered, and he went barefoot: and all the people that was with him covered every man his head, and they went up, weeping as they went up.
And*p one told David, saying, Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom. And David said, O Lord,*s I pray thee, turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness.
And*p it came to pass, that when David was come to the top of the mount, where he worshipped God, behold, Hushai the Archite came to meet him with his coat rent, and earth upon his head:
Unto*p whom David said, If thou passest on with me, then thou shalt be a burden unto me:

But*p if thou return to the city, and say unto Absalom, I will be thy servant, O king; as I have been thy father's servant hitherto, so will I now also be thy servant: then mayest thou for me defeat the counsel of Ahithophel.

And*p hast thou not there with thee Zadok and Abiathar the priests? therefore it shall be, that what thing soever thou shalt hear out of the king's house, thou shalt tell it to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
Behold,*p they have there with them their two sons, Ahimaaz Zadok's son, and Jonathan Abiathar's son; and by them ye shall send unto me every thing that ye can hear.
So*p Hushai David's friend came into the city, and Absalom came into Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 16

And*p when David was a little past the top of the hill, behold, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth met him, with a couple of asses saddled, and upon them two hundred loaves of bread, and an hundred bunches of raisins, and an hundred of summer fruits, and a bottle of wine.

And*p the king said unto Ziba, What meanest thou by these? And Ziba said, The asses be for the king's household to ride on; and the bread and summer fruit for the young men to eat; and the wine, that such as be faint in the wilderness may drink.
And*p the king said, And where is thy master's son? And Ziba said unto the king, Behold, he abideth at Jerusalem: for he said, To day shall the house of Israel restore me the kingdom of my father.
Then*p said the king to Ziba, Behold, thine are all that pertained unto Mephibosheth. And Ziba said, I humbly beseech thee that I may find grace in thy sight, my lord, O king.
And*p when king David came to Bahurim, behold, thence came out a man of the family of the house of Saul, whose name was Shimei, the son of Gera: he came forth, and cursed still as he came.
And*p he cast stones at David, and at all the servants of king David: and all the people and all the mighty men were on his right hand and on his left.
And*p thus said Shimei when he cursed, Come out, come out, thou bloody man, and thou man of Belial:

The*p Lord*s hath returned upon thee all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose stead thou hast reigned; and the Lord*s hath delivered the kingdom into the hand of Absalom thy son: and, behold, thou art taken in thy mischief, because thou art a bloody man.
Then*p said Abishai the son of Zeruiah unto the king, Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? let me go over, I pray thee, and take off his head.
And*p the king said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah? so let him curse, because the Lord*s hath said unto him, Curse David. Who shall then say, Wherefore hast thou done so?

And*p David said to Abishai, and to all his servants, Behold, my son, which came forth of my bowels, seeketh my life: how much more now may this Benjamite do it? let him alone, and let him curse; for the Lord*s hath bidden him.
It*p may be that the Lord*s will look on mine affliction, and that the Lord*s will requite me good for his cursing this day.
And*p as David and his men went by the way, Shimei went along on the hill's side over against him, and cursed as he went, and threw stones at him, and cast dust.
And*p the king, and all the people that were with him, came weary, and refreshed themselves there.
And*p Absalom, and all the people the men of Israel, came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel with him.
And*p it came to pass, when Hushai the Archite, David's friend, was come unto Absalom, that Hushai said unto Absalom, God save the king, God save the king.
And*p Absalom said to Hushai, Is this thy kindness to thy friend? why wentest thou not with thy friend?
And*p Hushai said unto Absalom, Nay; but whom the Lord,*s and this people, and all the men of Israel, choose, his will I be, and with him will I abide.
And*p again, whom should I serve? should I not serve in the presence of his son? as I have served in thy father's presence, so will I be in thy presence.
Then*p said Absalom to Ahithophel, Give counsel among you what we shall do.

And*p Ahithophel said unto Absalom, Go in unto thy father's concubines, which he hath left to keep the house; and all Israel shall hear that thou art abhorred of thy father: then shall the hands of all that are with thee be strong.
So*p they spread Absalom a tent upon the top of the house; and Absalom went in unto his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.
And*p the counsel of Ahithophel, which he counselled in those days, was as if a man had enquired at the oracle of God: so was all the counsel of Ahithophel both with David and with Absalom.
2 Samuel 17
Moreover*p Ahithophel said unto Absalom, Let me now choose out twelve thousand men, and I will arise and pursue after David this night:
And*p I will come upon him while he is weary and weak handed, and will make him afraid: and all the people that are with him shall flee; and I will smite the king only:
And*p I will bring back all the people unto thee: the man whom thou seekest is as if all returned: so all the people shall be in peace.
And*p the saying pleased Absalom well, and all the elders of Israel.
Then*p said Absalom, Call now Hushai the Archite also, and let us hear likewise what he saith.
And*p when Hushai was come to Absalom, Absalom spake unto him, saying, Ahithophel hath spoken after this manner: shall we do after his saying? if not; speak thou.
And*p Hushai said unto Absalom, The counsel that Ahithophel hath given is not good at this time.

For,*p said Hushai, thou knowest thy father and his men, that they be mighty men, and they be chafed in their minds, as a bear robbed of her whelps in the field: and thy father is a man of war, and will not lodge with the people.

Behold,*p he is hid now in some pit, or in some other place: and it will come to pass, when some of them be overthrown at the first, that whosoever heareth it will say, There is a slaughter among the people that follow Absalom.
And*p he also that is valiant, whose heart is as the heart of a lion, shall utterly melt: for all Israel knoweth that thy father is a mighty man, and they which be with him are valiant men.
Therefore*p I counsel that all Israel be generally gathered unto thee, from Dan even to Beer–sheba, as the sand that is by the sea for multitude; and that thou go to battle in thine own person.

So*p shall we come upon him in some place where he shall be found, and we will light upon him as the dew falleth on the ground: and of him and of all the men that are with him there shall not be left so much as one.
Moreover,*p if he be gotten into a city, then shall all Israel bring ropes to that city, and we will draw it into the river, until there be not one small stone found there.

And*p Absalom and all the men of Israel said, The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Ahithophel. For the Lord*s had appointed to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, to the intent that the Lord*s might bring evil upon Absalom.
Then*p said Hushai unto Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, Thus and thus did Ahithophel counsel Absalom and the elders of Israel; and thus and thus have I counselled.

Now*p therefore send quickly, and tell David, saying, Lodge not this night in the plains of the wilderness, but speedily pass over; lest the king be swallowed up, and all the people that are with him.
Now*p Jonathan and Ahimaaz stayed by En–rogel; for they might not be seen to come into the city: and a wench went and told them; and they went and told king David.
Nevertheless*p a lad saw them, and told Absalom: but they went both of them away quickly, and came to a man's house in Bahurim, which had a well in his court; whither they went down.
And*p the woman took and spread a covering over the well's mouth, and spread ground corn thereon; and the thing was not known.

And*p when Absalom's servants came to the woman to the house, they said, Where is Ahimaaz and Jonathan? And the woman said unto them, They be gone over the brook of water. And when they had sought and could not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.

And*p it came to pass, after they were departed, that they came up out of the well, and went and told king David, and said unto David, Arise, and pass quickly over the water: for thus hath Ahithophel counselled against you.
Then*p David arose, and all the people that were with him, and they passed over Jordan: by the morning light there lacked not one of them that was not gone over Jordan.

And*p when Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his ass, and arose, and gat him home to his house, to his city, and put his household in order, and hanged himself, and died, and was buried in the sepulchre of his father.
Then*p David came to Mahanaim. And Absalom passed over Jordan, he and all the men of Israel with him.

And*p Absalom made Amasa captain of the host instead of Joab: which Amasa was a man's son, whose name was Ithra an Israelite, that went in to Abigail the daughter of Nahash, sister to Zeruiah Joab's mother.
So*p Israel and Absalom pitched in the land of Gilead.

And*p it came to pass, when David was come to Mahanaim, that Shobi the son of Nahash of Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and Machir the son of Ammiel of Lo–debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite of Rogelim,
Brought*p beds, and basins, and earthen vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched corn, and beans, and lentiles, and parched pulse,
And*p honey, and butter, and sheep, and cheese of kine, for David, and for the people that were with him, to eat: for they said, The people is hungry, and weary, and thirsty, in the wilderness.
2 Samuel 18
And*p David numbered the people that were with him, and set captains of thousands and captains of hundreds over them.

And*p David sent forth a third part of the people under the hand of Joab, and a third part under the hand of Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab's brother, and a third part under the hand of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said unto the people, I will surely go forth with you myself also.

But*p the people answered, Thou shalt not go forth: for if we flee away, they will not care for us; neither if half of us die, will they care for us: but now thou art worth ten thousand of us: therefore now it is better that thou succour us out of the city.
And*p the king said unto them, What seemeth you best I will do. And the king stood by the gate side, and all the people came out by hundreds and by thousands.

And*p the king commanded Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, Deal gently for my sake with the young man, even with Absalom. And all the people heard when the king gave all the captains charge concerning Absalom.
So*p the people went out into the field against Israel: and the battle was in the wood of Ephraim;
Where*p the people of Israel were slain before the servants of David, and there was there a great slaughter that day of twenty thousand men.
For*p the battle was there scattered over the face of all the country: and the wood devoured more people that day than the sword devoured.

And*p Absalom met the servants of David. And Absalom rode upon a mule, and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great oak, and his head caught hold of the oak, and he was taken up between the heaven and the earth; and the mule that was under him went away.
And*p a certain man saw it, and told Joab, and said, Behold, I saw Absalom hanged in an oak.
And*p Joab said unto the man that told him, And, behold, thou sawest him, and why didst thou not smite him there to the ground? and I would have given thee ten shekels of silver, and a girdle.

And*p the man said unto Joab, Though I should receive a thousand shekels of silver in mine hand, yet would I not put forth mine hand against the king's son: for in our hearing the king charged thee and Abishai and Ittai, saying, Beware that none touch the young man Absalom.
Otherwise*p I should have wrought falsehood against mine own life: for there is no matter hid from the king, and thou thyself wouldest have set thyself against me.
Then*p said Joab, I may not tarry thus with thee. And he took three darts in his hand, and thrust them through the heart of Absalom, while he was yet alive in the midst of the oak.
And*p ten young men that bare Joab's armour compassed about and smote Absalom, and slew him.
And*p Joab blew the trumpet, and the people returned from pursuing after Israel: for Joab held back the people.
And*p they took Absalom, and cast him into a great pit in the wood, and laid a very great heap of stones upon him: and all Israel fled every one to his tent.

Now*p Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself a pillar, which is in the king's dale: for he said, I have no son to keep my name in remembrance: and he called the pillar after his own name: and it is called unto this day, Absalom's place.
Then*p said Ahimaaz the son of Zadok, Let me now run, and bear the king tidings, how that the Lord*s hath avenged him of his enemies.
And*p Joab said unto him, Thou shalt not bear tidings this day, but thou shalt bear tidings another day: but this day thou shalt bear no tidings, because the king's son is dead.
Then*p said Joab to Cushi, Go tell the king what thou hast seen. And Cushi bowed himself unto Joab, and ran.

Then*p said Ahimaaz the son of Zadok yet again to Joab, But howsoever, let me, I pray thee, also run after Cushi. And Joab said, Wherefore wilt thou run, my son, seeing that thou hast no tidings ready?
But*p howsoever, said he, let me run. And he said unto him, Run. Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain, and overran Cushi.
And*p David sat between the two gates: and the watchman went up to the roof over the gate unto the wall, and lifted up his eyes, and looked, and behold a man running alone.
And*p the watchman cried, and told the king. And the king said, If he be alone, there is tidings in his mouth. And he came apace, and drew near.
And*p the watchman saw another man running: and the watchman called unto the porter, and said, Behold another man running alone. And the king said, He also bringeth tidings.
And*p the watchman said, Me thinketh the running of the foremost is like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zadok. And the king said, He is a good man, and cometh with good tidings.

And*p Ahimaaz called, and said unto the king, All is well. And he fell down to the earth upon his face before the king, and said, Blessed be the Lord*s thy God, which hath delivered up the men that lifted up their hand against my lord the king.
And*p the king said, Is the young man Absalom safe? And Ahimaaz answered, When Joab sent the king's servant, and me thy servant, I saw a great tumult, but I knew not what it was.
And*p the king said unto him, Turn aside, and stand here. And he turned aside, and stood still.
And,*p behold, Cushi came; and Cushi said, Tidings, my lord the king: for the Lord*s hath avenged thee this day of all them that rose up against thee.
And*p the king said unto Cushi, Is the young man Absalom safe? And Cushi answered, The enemies of my lord the king, and all that rise against thee to do thee hurt, be as that young man is.

And*p the king was much moved, and went up to the chamber over the gate, and wept: and as he went, thus he said, O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! would God I had died for thee, O Absalom, my son, my son!
2 Samuel 19
And*p it was told Joab, Behold, the king weepeth and mourneth for Absalom.
And*p the victory that day was turned into mourning unto all the people: for the people heard say that day how the king was grieved for his son.
And*p the people gat them by stealth that day into the city, as people being ashamed steal away when they flee in battle.
But*p the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice, O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!

And*p Joab came into the house to the king, and said, Thou hast shamed this day the faces of all thy servants, which this day have saved thy life, and the lives of thy sons and of thy daughters, and the lives of thy wives, and the lives of thy concubines;

In*p that thou lovest thine enemies, and hatest thy friends. For thou hast declared this day, that thou regardest neither princes nor servants: for this day I perceive, that if Absalom had lived, and all we had died this day, then it had pleased thee well.

Now*p therefore arise, go forth, and speak comfortably unto thy servants: for I swear by the Lord,*s if thou go not forth, there will not tarry one with thee this night: and that will be worse unto thee than all the evil that befell thee from thy youth until now.

Then*p the king arose, and sat in the gate. And they told unto all the people, saying, Behold, the king doth sit in the gate. And all the people came before the king: for Israel had fled every man to his tent.

And*p all the people were at strife throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, The king saved us out of the hand of our enemies, and he delivered us out of the hand of the Philistines; and now he is fled out of the land for Absalom.
