And*p Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now therefore why speak ye not a word of bringing the king back?

And*p king David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, Speak unto the elders of Judah, saying, Why are ye the last to bring the king back to his house? seeing the speech of all Israel is come to the king, even to his house.
Ye*p are my brethren, ye are my bones and my flesh: wherefore then are ye the last to bring back the king?
And*p say ye to Amasa, Art thou not of my bone, and of my flesh? God do so to me, and more also, if thou be not captain of the host before me continually in the room of Joab.
And*p he bowed the heart of all the men of Judah, even as the heart of one man; so that they sent this word unto the king, Return thou, and all thy servants.
So*p the king returned, and came to Jordan. And Judah came to Gilgal, to go to meet the king, to conduct the king over Jordan.
And*p Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite, which was of Bahurim, hasted and came down with the men of Judah to meet king David.
And*p there were a thousand men of Benjamin with him, and Ziba the servant of the house of Saul, and his fifteen sons and his twenty servants with him; and they went over Jordan before the king.
And*p there went over a ferry boat to carry over the king's household, and to do what he thought good. And Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king, as he was come over Jordan;

And*p said unto the king, Let not my lord impute iniquity unto me, neither do thou remember that which thy servant did perversely the day that my lord the king went out of Jerusalem, that the king should take it to his heart.
For*p thy servant doth know that I have sinned: therefore, behold, I am come the first this day of all the house of Joseph to go down to meet my lord the king.
But*p Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered and said, Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord's*s anointed?

And*p David said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah, that ye should this day be adversaries unto me? shall there any man be put to death this day in Israel? for do not I know that I am this day king over Israel?
Therefore*p the king said unto Shimei, Thou shalt not die. And the king sware unto him.

And*p Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king, and had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes, from the day the king departed until the day he came again in peace.
And*p it came to pass, when he was come to Jerusalem to meet the king, that the king said unto him, Wherefore wentest not thou with me, Mephibosheth?
And*p he answered, My lord, O king, my servant deceived me: for thy servant said, I will saddle me an ass, that I may ride thereon, and go to the king; because thy servant is lame.
And*p he hath slandered thy servant unto my lord the king; but my lord the king is as an angel of God: do therefore what is good in thine eyes.

For*p all of my father's house were but dead men before my lord the king: yet didst thou set thy servant among them that did eat at thine own table. What right therefore have I yet to cry any more unto the king?
And*p the king said unto him, Why speakest thou any more of thy matters? I have said, Thou and Ziba divide the land.
And*p Mephibosheth said unto the king, Yea, let him take all, forasmuch as my lord the king is come again in peace unto his own house.
And*p Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim, and went over Jordan with the king, to conduct him over Jordan.
Now*p Barzillai was a very aged man, even fourscore years old: and he had provided the king of sustenance while he lay at Mahanaim; for he was a very great man.
And*p the king said unto Barzillai, Come thou over with me, and I will feed thee with me in Jerusalem.
And*p Barzillai said unto the king, How long have I to live, that I should go up with the king unto Jerusalem?

I*p am this day fourscore years old: and can I discern between good and evil? can thy servant taste what I eat or what I drink? can I hear any more the voice of singing men and singing women? wherefore then should thy servant be yet a burden unto my lord the king?
Thy*p servant will go a little way over Jordan with the king: and why should the king recompense it me with such a reward?

Let*p thy servant, I pray thee, turn back again, that I may die in mine own city, and be buried by the grave of my father and of my mother. But behold thy servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king; and do to him what shall seem good unto thee.
And*p the king answered, Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do to him that which shall seem good unto thee: and whatsoever thou shalt require of me, that will I do for thee.
And*p all the people went over Jordan. And when the king was come over, the king kissed Barzillai, and blessed him; and he returned unto his own place.
Then*p the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him: and all the people of Judah conducted the king, and also half the people of Israel.

And,*p behold, all the men of Israel came to the king, and said unto the king, Why have our brethren the men of Judah stolen thee away, and have brought the king, and his household, and all David's men with him, over Jordan?

And*p all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, Because the king is near of kin to us: wherefore then be ye angry for this matter? have we eaten at all of the king's cost? or hath he given us any gift?

And*p the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and said, We have ten parts in the king, and we have also more right in David than ye: why then did ye despise us, that our advice should not be first had in bringing back our king? And the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel.
2 Samuel 20

And*p there happened to be there a man of Belial, whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite: and he blew a trumpet, and said, We have no part in David, neither have we inheritance in the son of Jesse: every man to his tents, O Israel.
So*p every man of Israel went up from after David, and followed Sheba the son of Bichri: but the men of Judah clave unto their king, from Jordan even to Jerusalem.

And*p David came to his house at Jerusalem; and the king took the ten women his concubines, whom he had left to keep the house, and put them in ward, and fed them, but went not in unto them. So they were shut up unto the day of their death, living in widowhood.
Then*p said the king to Amasa, Assemble me the men of Judah within three days, and be thou here present.
So*p Amasa went to assemble the men of Judah: but he tarried longer than the set time which he had appointed him.
And*p David said to Abishai, Now shall Sheba the son of Bichri do us more harm than did Absalom: take thou thy lord's servants, and pursue after him, lest he get him fenced cities, and escape us.
And*p there went out after him Joab's men, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and all the mighty men: and they went out of Jerusalem, to pursue after Sheba the son of Bichri.

When*p they were at the great stone which is in Gibeon, Amasa went before them. And Joab's garment that he had put on was girded unto him, and upon it a girdle with a sword fastened upon his loins in the sheath thereof; and as he went forth it fell out.
And*p Joab said to Amasa, Art thou in health, my brother? And Joab took Amasa by the beard with the right hand to kiss him.

But*p Amasa took no heed to the sword that was in Joab's hand: so he smote him therewith in the fifth rib, and shed out his bowels to the ground, and struck him not again; and he died. So Joab and Abishai his brother pursued after Sheba the son of Bichri.
And*p one of Joab's men stood by him, and said, He that favoureth Joab, and he that is for David, let him go after Joab.

And*p Amasa wallowed in blood in the midst of the highway. And when the man saw that all the people stood still, he removed Amasa out of the highway into the field, and cast a cloth upon him, when he saw that every one that came by him stood still.
When*p he was removed out of the highway, all the people went on after Joab, to pursue after Sheba the son of Bichri.
And*p he went through all the tribes of Israel unto Abel, and to Beth–maachah, and all the Berites: and they were gathered together, and went also after him.

And*p they came and besieged him in Abel of Beth–maachah, and they cast up a bank against the city, and it stood in the trench: and all the people that were with Joab battered the wall, to throw it down.
Then*p cried a wise woman out of the city, Hear, hear; say, I pray you, unto Joab, Come near hither, that I may speak with thee.
And*p when he was come near unto her, the woman said, Art thou Joab? And he answered, I am he. Then she said unto him, Hear the words of thine handmaid. And he answered, I do hear.
Then*p she spake, saying, They were wont to speak in old time, saying, They shall surely ask counsel at Abel: and so they ended the matter.
I*p am one of them that are peaceable and faithful in Israel: thou seekest to destroy a city and a mother in Israel: why wilt thou swallow up the inheritance of the Lord?*s
And*p Joab answered and said, Far be it, far be it from me, that I should swallow up or destroy.

The*p matter is not so: but a man of mount Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bichri by name, hath lifted up his hand against the king, even against David: deliver him only, and I will depart from the city. And the woman said unto Joab, Behold, his head shall be thrown to thee over the wall.

Then*p the woman went unto all the people in her wisdom. And they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri, and cast it out to Joab. And he blew a trumpet, and they retired from the city, every man to his tent. And Joab returned to Jerusalem unto the king.
Now*p Joab was over all the host of Israel: and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and over the Pelethites:
And*p Adoram was over the tribute: and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder:
And*p Sheva was scribe: and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests:
And*p Ira also the Jairite was a chief ruler about David.
2 Samuel 21

Then*p there was a famine in the days of David three years, year after year; and David enquired of the Lord.*s And the Lord*s answered, It is for Saul, and for his bloody house, because he slew the Gibeonites.

And*p the king called the Gibeonites, and said unto them; (now the Gibeonites were not of the children of Israel, but of the remnant of the Amorites; and the children of Israel had sworn unto them: and Saul sought to slay them in his zeal to the children of Israel and Judah.)
Wherefore*p David said unto the Gibeonites, What shall I do for you? and wherewith shall I make the atonement, that ye may bless the inheritance of the Lord?*s

And*p the Gibeonites said unto him, We will have no silver nor gold of Saul, nor of his house; neither for us shalt thou kill any man in Israel. And he said, What ye shall say, that will I do for you.
And*p they answered the king, The man that consumed us, and that devised against us that we should be destroyed from remaining in any of the coasts of Israel,
Let*p seven men of his sons be delivered unto us, and we will hang them up unto the Lord*s in Gibeah of Saul, whom the Lord*s did choose. And the king said, I will give them.
But*p the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan the son of Saul, because of the Lord's*s oath that was between them, between David and Jonathan the son of Saul.

But*p the king took the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, whom she bare unto Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth; and the five sons of Michal the daughter of Saul, whom she brought up for Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite:

And*p he delivered them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them in the hill before the Lord:*s and they fell all seven together, and were put to death in the days of harvest, in the first days, in the beginning of barley harvest.

And*p Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth, and spread it for her upon the rock, from the beginning of harvest until water dropped upon them out of heaven, and suffered neither the birds of the air to rest on them by day, nor the beasts of the field by night.
And*p it was told David what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done.

And*p David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the men of Jabesh–gilead, which had stolen them from the street of Beth–shan, where the Philistines had hanged them, when the Philistines had slain Saul in Gilboa:
And*p he brought up from thence the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son; and they gathered the bones of them that were hanged.

And*p the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son buried they in the country of Benjamin in Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish his father: and they performed all that the king commanded. And after that God was entreated for the land.
Moreover*p the Philistines had yet war again with Israel; and David went down, and his servants with him, and fought against the Philistines: and David waxed faint.
And*p Ishbi–benob, which was of the sons of the giant, the weight of whose spear weighed three hundred shekels of brass in weight, he being girded with a new sword, thought to have slain David.

But*p Abishai the son of Zeruiah succoured him, and smote the Philistine, and killed him. Then the men of David sware unto him, saying, Thou shalt go no more out with us to battle, that thou quench not the light of Israel.
And*p it came to pass after this, that there was again a battle with the Philistines at Gob: then Sibbecai the Hushathite slew Saph, which was of the sons of the giant.

And*p there was again a battle in Gob with the Philistines, where Elhanan the son of Jaare–oregim, a Beth–lehemite, slew the brother of Goliath the Gittite, the staff of whose spear was like a weaver's beam.
And*p there was yet a battle in Gath, where was a man of great stature, that had on every hand six fingers, and on every foot six toes, four and twenty in number; and he also was born to the giant.
And*p when he defied Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimeah the brother of David slew him.
These*p four were born to the giant in Gath, and fell by the hand of David, and by the hand of his servants.
2 Samuel 22
And*p David spake unto the Lord*s the words of this song in the day that the Lord*s had delivered him out of the hand of all his enemies, and out of the hand of Saul:
And*p he said, The Lord*s is my rock, and my fortress, and my deliverer;
The*p God of my rock; in him will I trust: he is my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my high tower, and my refuge, my saviour; thou savest me from violence.
I*p will call on the Lord,*s who is worthy to be praised: so shall I be saved from mine enemies.
When*p the waves of death compassed me, the floods of ungodly men made me afraid;
The*p sorrows of hell compassed me about; the snares of death prevented me;
In*p my distress I called upon the Lord,*s and cried to my God: and he did hear my voice out of his temple, and my cry did enter into his ears.
Then*p the earth shook and trembled; the foundations of heaven moved and shook, because he was wroth.
There*p went up a smoke out of his nostrils, and fire out of his mouth devoured: coals were kindled by it.
He*p bowed the heavens also, and came down; and darkness was under his feet.
And*p he rode upon a cherub, and did fly: and he was seen upon the wings of the wind.
And*p he made darkness pavilions round about him, dark waters, and thick clouds of the skies.
Through*p the brightness before him were coals of fire kindled.
The*p Lord*s thundered from heaven, and the most High uttered his voice.
And*p he sent out arrows, and scattered them; lightning, and discomfited them.
And*p the channels of the sea appeared, the foundations of the world were discovered, at the rebuking of the Lord,*s at the blast of the breath of his nostrils.
He*p sent from above, he took me; he drew me out of many waters;
He*p delivered me from my strong enemy, and from them that hated me: for they were too strong for me.
They*p prevented me in the day of my calamity: but the Lord*s was my stay.
He*p brought me forth also into a large place: he delivered me, because he delighted in me.
The*p Lord*s rewarded me according to my righteousness: according to the cleanness of my hands hath he recompensed me.
For*p I have kept the ways of the Lord,*s and have not wickedly departed from my God.
For*p all his judgments were before me: and as for his statutes, I did not depart from them.
I*p was also upright before him, and have kept myself from mine iniquity.
Therefore*p the Lord*s hath recompensed me according to my righteousness; according to my cleanness in his eye sight.
With*p the merciful thou wilt shew thyself merciful, and with the upright man thou wilt shew thyself upright.
With*p the pure thou wilt shew thyself pure; and with the froward thou wilt shew thyself unsavoury.
And*p the afflicted people thou wilt save: but thine eyes are upon the haughty, that thou mayest bring them down.
For*p thou art my lamp, O Lord:*s and the Lord*s will lighten my darkness.
For*p by thee I have run through a troop: by my God have I leaped over a wall.
As*p for God, his way is perfect; the word of the Lord*s is tried: he is a buckler to all them that trust in him.
For*p who is God, save the Lord?*s and who is a rock, save our God?
God*p is my strength and power: and he maketh my way perfect.
He*p maketh my feet like hinds' feet: and setteth me upon my high places.
He*p teacheth my hands to war; so that a bow of steel is broken by mine arms.
Thou*p hast also given me the shield of thy salvation: and thy gentleness hath made me great.
Thou*p hast enlarged my steps under me; so that my feet did not slip.
I*p have pursued mine enemies, and destroyed them; and turned not again until I had consumed them.
And*p I have consumed them, and wounded them, that they could not arise: yea, they are fallen under my feet.
For*p thou hast girded me with strength to battle: them that rose up against me hast thou subdued under me.
Thou*p hast also given me the necks of mine enemies, that I might destroy them that hate me.
They*p looked, but there was none to save; even unto the Lord,*s but he answered them not.
Then*p did I beat them as small as the dust of the earth, I did stamp them as the mire of the street, and did spread them abroad.
Thou*p also hast delivered me from the strivings of my people, thou hast kept me to be head of the heathen: a people which I knew not shall serve me.
Strangers*p shall submit themselves unto me: as soon as they hear, they shall be obedient unto me.
Strangers*p shall fade away, and they shall be afraid out of their close places.
The*p Lord*s liveth; and blessed be my rock; and exalted be the God of the rock of my salvation.
It*p is God that avengeth me, and that bringeth down the people under me,
And*p that bringeth me forth from mine enemies: thou also hast lifted me up on high above them that rose up against me: thou hast delivered me from the violent man.
Therefore*p I will give thanks unto thee, O Lord,*s among the heathen, and I will sing praises unto thy name.
He*p is the tower of salvation for his king: and sheweth mercy to his anointed, unto David, and to his seed for evermore.
2 Samuel 23
Now*p these be the last words of David. David the son of Jesse said, and the man who was raised up on high, the anointed of the God of Jacob, and the sweet psalmist of Israel, said,
The*p Spirit of the Lord*s spake by me, and his word was in my tongue.
The*p God of Israel said, the Rock of Israel spake to me, He that ruleth over men must be just, ruling in the fear of God.
And*p he shall be as the light of the morning, when the sun riseth, even a morning without clouds; as the tender grass springing out of the earth by clear shining after rain.

Although*p my house be not so with God; yet he hath made with me an everlasting covenant, ordered in all things, and sure: for this is all my salvation, and all my desire, although he make it not to grow.
But*p the sons of Belial shall be all of them as thorns thrust away, because they cannot be taken with hands:
But*p the man that shall touch them must be fenced with iron and the staff of a spear; and they shall be utterly burned with fire in the same place.

These*p be the names of the mighty men whom David had: The Tachmonite that sat in the seat, chief among the captains; the same was Adino the Eznite: he lift up his spear against eight hundred, whom he slew at one time.

And*p after him was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the three mighty men with David, when they defied the Philistines that were there gathered together to battle, and the men of Israel were gone away:
He*p arose, and smote the Philistines until his hand was weary, and his hand clave unto the sword: and the Lord*s wrought a great victory that day; and the people returned after him only to spoil.

And*p after him was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. And the Philistines were gathered together into a troop, where was a piece of ground full of lentiles: and the people fled from the Philistines.
But*p he stood in the midst of the ground, and defended it, and slew the Philistines: and the Lord*s wrought a great victory.
And*p three of the thirty chief went down, and came to David in the harvest time unto the cave of Adullam: and the troop of the Philistines pitched in the valley of Rephaim.
And*p David was then in an hold, and the garrison of the Philistines was then in Beth–lehem.
And*p David longed, and said, Oh that one would give me drink of the water of the well of Beth–lehem, which is by the gate!

And*p the three mighty men brake through the host of the Philistines, and drew water out of the well of Beth–lehem, that was by the gate, and took it, and brought it to David: nevertheless he would not drink thereof, but poured it out unto the Lord.*s

And*p he said, Be it far from me, O Lord,*s that I should do this: is not this the blood of the men that went in jeopardy of their lives? therefore he would not drink it. These things did these three mighty men.
And*p Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was chief among three. And he lifted up his spear against three hundred, and slew them, and had the name among three.
Was*p he not most honourable of three? therefore he was their captain: howbeit he attained not unto the first three.

And*p Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a valiant man, of Kabzeel, who had done many acts, he slew two lionlike men of Moab: he went down also and slew a lion in the midst of a pit in time of snow:

And*p he slew an Egyptian, a goodly man: and the Egyptian had a spear in his hand; but he went down to him with a staff, and plucked the spear out of the Egyptian's hand, and slew him with his own spear.
These*p things did Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and had the name among three mighty men.
He*p was more honourable than the thirty, but he attained not to the first three. And David set him over his guard.
Asahel*p the brother of Joab was one of the thirty; Elhanan the son of Dodo of Beth–lehem,
Shammah*p the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
Helez*p the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
Abiezer*p the Anathothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
Zalmon*p the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
Heleb*p the son of Baanah, a Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai out of Gibeah of the children of Benjamin,
Benaiah*p the Pirathonite, Hiddai of the brooks of Gaash,
Abi–albon*p the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
Eliahba*p the Shaalbonite, of the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,
Shammah*p the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite,
Eliphelet*p the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maachathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
Hezrai*p the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
Igal*p the son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
Zelek*p the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, armourbearer to Joab the son of Zeruiah,
Ira*p an Ithrite, Gareb an Ithrite,
Uriah*p the Hittite: thirty and seven in all.
2 Samuel 24
And*p again the anger of the Lord*s was kindled against Israel, and he moved David against them to say, Go, number Israel and Judah.

For*p the king said to Joab the captain of the host, which was with him, Go now through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan even to Beer–sheba, and number ye the people, that I may know the number of the people.

And*p Joab said unto the king, Now the Lord*s thy God add unto the people, how many soever they be, an hundredfold, and that the eyes of my lord the king may see it: but why doth my lord the king delight in this thing?

Notwithstanding*p the king's word prevailed against Joab, and against the captains of the host. And Joab and the captains of the host went out from the presence of the king, to number the people of Israel.
And*p they passed over Jordan, and pitched in Aroer, on the right side of the city that lieth in the midst of the river of Gad, and toward Jazer:
Then*p they came to Gilead, and to the land of Tahtim–hodshi; and they came to Dan–jaan, and about to Zidon,
And*p came to the strong hold of Tyre, and to all the cities of the Hivites, and of the Canaanites: and they went out to the south of Judah, even to Beer–sheba.
So*p when they had gone through all the land, they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.

And*p Joab gave up the sum of the number of the people unto the king: and there were in Israel eight hundred thousand valiant men that drew the sword; and the men of Judah were five hundred thousand men.

And*p David's heart smote him after that he had numbered the people. And David said unto the Lord,*s I have sinned greatly in that I have done: and now, I beseech thee, O Lord,*s take away the iniquity of thy servant; for I have done very foolishly.
For*p when David was up in the morning, the word of the Lord*s came unto the prophet Gad, David's seer, saying,
Go*p and say unto David, Thus saith the Lord,*s I offer thee three things; choose thee one of them, that I may do it unto thee.

So*p Gad came to David, and told him, and said unto him, Shall seven years of famine come unto thee in thy land? or wilt thou flee three months before thine enemies, while they pursue thee? or that there be three days' pestilence in thy land? now advise, and see what answer I shall return to him that sent me.
And*p David said unto Gad, I am in a great strait: let us fall now into the hand of the Lord;*s for his mercies are great: and let me not fall into the hand of man.
So*p the Lord*s sent a pestilence upon Israel from the morning even to the time appointed: and there died of the people from Dan even to Beer–sheba seventy thousand men.

And*p when the angel stretched out his hand upon Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord*s repented him of the evil, and said to the angel that destroyed the people, It is enough: stay now thine hand. And the angel of the Lord*s was by the threshingplace of Araunah the Jebusite.

And*p David spake unto the Lord*s when he saw the angel that smote the people, and said, Lo, I have sinned, and I have done wickedly: but these sheep, what have they done? let thine hand, I pray thee, be against me, and against my father's house.
And*p Gad came that day to David, and said unto him, Go up, rear an altar unto the Lord*s in the threshingfloor of Araunah the Jebusite.
And*p David, according to the saying of Gad, went up as the Lord*s commanded.
And*p Araunah looked, and saw the king and his servants coming on toward him: and Araunah went out, and bowed himself before the king on his face upon the ground.

And*p Araunah said, Wherefore is my lord the king come to his servant? And David said, To buy the threshingfloor of thee, to build an altar unto the Lord,*s that the plague may be stayed from the people.

And*p Araunah said unto David, Let my lord the king take and offer up what seemeth good unto him: behold, here be oxen for burnt sacrifice, and threshing instruments and other instruments of the oxen for wood.
All*p these things did Araunah, as a king, give unto the king. And Araunah said unto the king, The Lord*s thy God accept thee.

And*p the king said unto Araunah, Nay; but I will surely buy it of thee at a price: neither will I offer burnt offerings unto the Lord*s my God of that which doth cost me nothing. So David bought the threshingfloor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
And*p David built there an altar unto the Lord,*s and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. So the Lord*s was entreated for the land, and the plague was stayed from Israel.
